summary: fear not for the future; weep not for the past
title: fear not for the future; weep not for the past
body:
In honor of the trailer, which we have waited for for far too long! Another ridiculous take on Jon assuming his parenthood, though this is… less humorous? Idk, but it does take up the task of explaining the Jon & Catelyn relationship of my dreams!

[In which Catelyn knows the truth, and tells Jon while Ned’s off on a state trip.]

…

“If you hate me that’s fine,” Jon said, sharply, before turning and running.

Catelyn sighed, inwardly and out. Jon was a better kid than Robb- easier, at least, being both quieter and less temperamental all at once. But when he got angry he tended to stay angry, and he also had a terrible habit of running into the woods when he felt like being alone.

With Ned off to Castle Cerwyn for a week with delegations from all seven kingdoms, and Jon having apparently been in such a bad mood as to snap at Arya and make her cry- Arya, crying, over something unrelated to chores!- Catelyn had confronted him, and the boy had shouted for well over a quarter hour before fleeing. But now she had a good idea of what was bothering him, and Catelyn didn’t feel remotely ready to deal with it.

Though- staying silent would likely be crueler than telling the truth.

Jon deserved the truth.

She’d fought over that very point with Ned, before he left. Jon hadn’t been so suspicious of his mother’s personality then, though, and yes, if Catelyn told him the truth there would likely be a moon’s turn of irritated looks from her husband to deal with, not to mention a cold bed.

And yet.

Jon deserved the truth.

Mind made up, Catelyn made her way towards the godswood. She didn’t bother to look at the trees, where Robb always liked to hide; Jon liked his feet planted on solid ground, and Winterfell’s swordsmaster had spent years training that flatfootedness out of him. Instead, she looked at the shadows.

And there he was: Jon, curled into a ball that made him look smaller than his gangly years; hidden in the dark curve of a sycamore overlooking the pools.

Carefully, Catelyn picked her path through the snow and leaves, until she was close enough to feel the heat of the pools’ steam on her frozen fingers.

“I’ve never hated you.”

“Like I’ve never hated you?” was the immediate response.

That stung. Catelyn hadn’t ever been so close to Jon, that was true enough; but she’d never hated him either. To think that he had wasn’t a pleasant thought.

He’s a child.

“This is about your mother,” she said, instead, keeping her voice soothing.

“Everything is about her,” Jon replied bitterly, after a long pause. “Everyone else knows, though, and it was staring at me all along. You-”

“Everyone knows?” Catelyn demanded. Adrenaline jolted through her, but she forced herself to stay calm. 

“Did you know her?” Jon asked flatly, head poking out of the shadows to level a look almost exactly like Ned’s at her. He sounded more hesitant than angry now, and Catelyn thought she could all but taste the desire soaking through his voice. Yes, she decided. Ned was wrong to keep this from him. “Was she- how was she?”

“She was very pretty,” Catelyn said slowly. She’d met Lyanna Stark for all of a few minutes at Harrenhal’s Tourney before the girl had run off; what she’d heard of her since hadn’t been very complimentary.

But Ned had loved her- still loved her- and Jon was her only child. Catelyn wouldn’t taint those memories with her own suspicions.

“Pretty, and bright. She could wield a sword better than half the men her age, and if her father had allowed it, she’d likely have entered all the tourneys in the world. And when you’re as small as she was- it’s courage and brains that won her battles, until the last. Ned tells me you get that from her.”

Lyanna’s brains, had been his actual words, and not an ounce of her ambition. He’d disappear for the Wall if I allowed it, accept the black and the oaths without a second glance.

Sounds like her brother, Catelyn had replied, just as Jon disarmed Robb with a flick of his sword that looked impressive even to her. Ned had looked so surprised, and Catelyn had smiled, slow and wide. He is your son as well, Ned, now. And just because he holds his words important doesn’t make him a fool. Or have you forgotten who challenged Theon Greyjoy to a duel of honor when he was not but ten?

“What did she- look like?”

“Long hair,” Catelyn murmured, eyes closing. “Dark as yours. You’ve her eyes, as well, the shape and the size- though the color’s all Ned’s. Arya’s, as well. Your grandmother’s, apparently.”

“You’re lying to me!” 

Catelyn jerked away, nearly losing her balance on the leaf-strewn ground. When she straightened, Jon’s hands were fisted at his sides and he looked mulishly stubborn. Like Ned had looked, back when Catelyn first pushed him- irritated; somber; regretful but not repenting.

“Her eyes were purple,” said Jon, and the disgust seemed to swallow him whole. “That’s what that Dornish ambassador said! Her eyes were purple, and she killed herself, and-”

She twisted to fully meet Jon, face to face, and asked sharply, “Who did you think your mother was, Jon?”

He shrank back, just a little, at Catelyn’s face, before straightening defiantly. “Ashara,” he said. “Ashara Dayne.”

“Ah.” Surprise left Catelyn faint. She considered letting Jon keep believing in the lie- it was easier, all truth told- but unfair, in the end, to Ashara Dayne’s memory, to Ned’s own honor, and to this little boy standing in front of her. “I see why you’d believe that.”

“But it isn’t true,” Jon said, defeated.

“No,” said Catelyn gently. She reached forward and wrapped her hand over Jon’s shoulder, using the leverage to sink to her knees in front of him. “No, it isn’t true. But it is past time you knew, I think.”

He stilled, body like stone under her fingers. His eyes- so similar to Ned’s; so dissimilar, too: more hurting, more angry, more bitter- didn’t look away from her.

“Ned didn’t tell you at first because it was dangerous,” Catelyn explained. Better Jon understood this before it was overshadowed by the revelation. If Jon were to spill even a hint of it to anyone- the consequences could be disastrous. “Children have loose lips; and if news reached the King, there might not have been much left of us Starks by the time he was done with us. Better you remain ignorant and loved and safe, Ned thought, even if it was all a lie.”

“Father… committed treason?” Jon whispered. 

“At the end of Robert’s Rebellion, he went to Dorne to find his sister, Lyanna. He found her at the Tower of Joy and slew Arthur Dayne, two others of the Kingsguard- and he entered the tower to find her on a bed of roses and blood.” Oh, how Catelyn had had nightmares after Ned had told her! How cruel the world had been to Lyanna Stark, to Ned, to all those Ned had once named family! “She did not live to see dusk, but she was not alone in the tower. For beside her was a babe, just a few days old.”

Jon frowned. “A babe?” Then, realizing: “Me.”

“Yes,” affirmed Catelyn. “You.”

“But then- my father wasn’t- isn’t-”

“Lyanna was stolen away by a man,” said Catelyn, watching Jon sadly. “Do you remember who?”

He looked numb. Shell-shocked.

“Rhaegar Targaryen.”

“And a son of Rhaegar Targaryen would be…”

“A prince.”

“Not a prince,” corrected Catelyn. “The crown prince. And with Rhaegar dead? He’d be king.”

Jon shook his head. “Nobody’s going to ride to give me a- a- throne. Nobody.”

“And that matters little.” Catelyn cupped his jaw and brushed a lock of hair from Jon’s forehead. “The things Robert Baratheon is known for- restraint is not one of them. He attacks threats with his hammer, and beats them until their blood turns rivers red.” A gruesome picture- she did regret how Jon turned white and strained- but also necessary. Better he be wary now than careless. And if he remembered how Rhaegar died, all to the better. “Do you see why we wished to keep it silent?”

Understand. Understand that there are no easy choices in this. Understand that we have done the best we can.

Slowly, Jon nodded. 

“Yes,” he whispered. “I do.”

Catelyn let her hand drop, and bowed her head. Jon left, but Catelyn remained, silent, shrouded in shadows, under trees that left her shivering and frightened. Finally, she rose and almost walked away, but then paused at the edge to the godswood.

The best we can, she thought, remembering rumors from the south that Robert would ride north soon. Let us pray it will be enough.

But Ned had loved her- still loved her- and Jon was her only child. Catelyn wouldn’t taint those memories with her own suspicions.

“Pretty, and bright. She could wield a sword better than half the men her age, and if her father had allowed it, she’d likely have entered all the tourneys in the world. And when you’re as small as she was- it’s courage and brains that won her battles, until the last. Ned tells me you get that from her.”

Lyanna’s brains, had been his actual words, and not an ounce of her ambition. He’d disappear for the Wall if I allowed it, accept the black and the oaths without a second glance.

Sounds like her brother, Catelyn had replied, just as Jon disarmed Robb with a flick of his sword that looked impressive even to her. Ned had looked so surprised, and Catelyn had smiled, slow and wide. He is your son as well, Ned, now. And just because he holds his words important doesn’t make him a fool. Or have you forgotten who challenged Theon Greyjoy to a duel of honor when he was not but ten?

“What did she- look like?”

“Long hair,” Catelyn murmured, eyes closing. “Dark as yours. You’ve her eyes, as well, the shape and the size- though the color’s all Ned’s. Arya’s, as well. Your grandmother’s, apparently.”

“You’re lying to me!” 

Catelyn jerked away, nearly losing her balance on the leaf-strewn ground. When she straightened, Jon’s hands were fisted at his sides and he looked mulishly stubborn. Like Ned had looked, back when Catelyn first pushed him- irritated; somber; regretful but not repenting.

“Her eyes were purple,” said Jon, and the disgust seemed to swallow him whole. “That’s what that Dornish ambassador said! Her eyes were purple, and she killed herself, and-”

She twisted to fully meet Jon, face to face, and asked sharply, “Who did you think your mother was, Jon?”

He shrank back, just a little, at Catelyn’s face, before straightening defiantly. “Ashara,” he said. “Ashara Dayne.”

“Ah.” Surprise left Catelyn faint. She considered letting Jon keep believing in the lie- it was easier, all truth told- but unfair, in the end, to Ashara Dayne’s memory, to Ned’s own honor, and to this little boy standing in front of her. “I see why you’d believe that.”

“But it isn’t true,” Jon said, defeated.

“No,” said Catelyn gently. She reached forward and wrapped her hand over Jon’s shoulder, using the leverage to sink to her knees in front of him. “No, it isn’t true. But it is past time you knew, I think.”

He stilled, body like stone under her fingers. His eyes- so similar to Ned’s; so dissimilar, too: more hurting, more angry, more bitter- didn’t look away from her.

“Ned didn’t tell you at first because it was dangerous,” Catelyn explained. Better Jon understood this before it was overshadowed by the revelation. If Jon were to spill even a hint of it to anyone- the consequences could be disastrous. “Children have loose lips; and if news reached the King, there might not have been much left of us Starks by the time he was done with us. Better you remain ignorant and loved and safe, Ned thought, even if it was all a lie.”

“Father… committed treason?” Jon whispered. 

“At the end of Robert’s Rebellion, he went to Dorne to find his sister, Lyanna. He found her at the Tower of Joy and slew Arthur Dayne, two others of the Kingsguard- and he entered the tower to find her on a bed of roses and blood.” Oh, how Catelyn had had nightmares after Ned had told her! How cruel the world had been to Lyanna Stark, to Ned, to all those Ned had once named family! “She did not live to see dusk, but she was not alone in the tower. For beside her was a babe, just a few days old.”

Jon frowned. “A babe?” Then, realizing: “Me.”

“Yes,” affirmed Catelyn. “You.”

“But then- my father wasn’t- isn’t-”

“Lyanna was stolen away by a man,” said Catelyn, watching Jon sadly. “Do you remember who?”

He looked numb. Shell-shocked.

“Rhaegar Targaryen.”

“And a son of Rhaegar Targaryen would be…”

“A prince.”

“Not a prince,” corrected Catelyn. “The crown prince. And with Rhaegar dead? He’d be king.”

Jon shook his head. “Nobody’s going to ride to give me a- a- throne. Nobody.”

“And that matters little.” Catelyn cupped his jaw and brushed a lock of hair from Jon’s forehead. “The things Robert Baratheon is known for- restraint is not one of them. He attacks threats with his hammer, and beats them until their blood turns rivers red.” A gruesome picture- she did regret how Jon turned white and strained- but also necessary. Better he be wary now than careless. And if he remembered how Rhaegar died, all to the better. “Do you see why we wished to keep it silent?”

Understand. Understand that there are no easy choices in this. Understand that we have done the best we can.

Slowly, Jon nodded. 

“Yes,” he whispered. “I do.”

Catelyn let her hand drop, and bowed her head. Jon left, but Catelyn remained, silent, shrouded in shadows, under trees that left her shivering and frightened. Finally, she rose and almost walked away, but then paused at the edge to the godswood.

The best we can, she thought, remembering rumors from the south that Robert would ride north soon. Let us pray it will be enough.

“If you hate me that’s fine,” Jon said, sharply, before turning and running.

Catelyn sighed, inwardly and out. Jon was a better kid than Robb- easier, at least, being both quieter and less temperamental all at once. But when he got angry he tended to stay angry, and he also had a terrible habit of running into the woods when he felt like being alone.

But now she had a good idea of what was bothering him, and Catelyn didn’t feel remotely ready to deal with it.

Though- staying silent would likely be crueler than telling the truth.

Jon deserved the truth.

She’d fought over that very point with Ned, before he left. Jon hadn’t been so suspicious of his mother’s personality then, though, and yes, if Catelyn told him the truth there would likely be a moon’s turn of irritated looks from her husband to deal with, not to mention a cold bed.

Jon deserved the truth.

Carefully, Catelyn picked her path through the snow and leaves, until she was close enough to feel the heat of the pools’ steam on her frozen fingers.

“Like I’ve never hated you?” was the immediate response.

That stung. Catelyn hadn’t ever been so close to Jon, that was true enough; but she’d never hated him either. To think that he had wasn’t a pleasant thought.

summary: This is how I see it going down from piecing the trailer and promo shots together: in episode 1-2 Jon and family learn the truth...
question: This is how I see it going down from piecing the trailer and promo shots together: in episode 1-2 Jon and family learn the truth but don’t tell Dany. Ed/Tormund/Beric arrive with news about the wall (hence Dany looking upset in her black/red outfit). Jon in the crypts upset about the wall and about his parentage. Dany comes down to apologize/comfort about the wall/viserion (and seek comfort). They go together on dragonback to survey the aotd.
answer:
Hi, anons!

Both the crypts scene and Jon and D*ny approaching the dragons make the audience assume two things based on popular theories and headcanons: 

  • After the reveal, Jon will seek out the crypts and D*ny will comfort him
  • At some point, D*ny will re-introduce him to the dragons and he’ll learn how to fly

So if things really are as obvious as they seem, it would ruin the suspense and tension of two very important scenes. D&D wouldn’t want to spoil that; therefore, I’m positive they put them in the trailer because our preconceived notions prevent us from figuring out what what’s really going on.

Exactly what’s going on, though…

That’s not normal brooding Jon. Copy his expression. How does it feel? The way he holds his mouth, the tension in his chin… Honestly, it’s not easy reading facial expressions when it’s this dark and the quality is so bad (and he’s out of focus too) so I’m probably a bit off. But I feel like he’s incredibly upset and holding back his anger and frustration and resentment. I think that’s the feeling I’m looking for. Not purely. He’s sad too and almost a bit despondent, but there’s resentment there, something he can’t let her see, and so he can’t even let his lip twitch the way it does when he’s trying to control his anger.

And considering how not welcoming he is to her, how he doesn’t reach out, doesn’t start turning his face toward her until she’s really close, and his expression doesn’t change… His reason for being upset has to do with her in some capacity–and she knows it. This isn’t a normal thing for her to do, to reach out like this, so softly and tentatively.

So what can it be?

  • The Dothraki have raided a settlement - I find this less likely, tbh. My gut says it’s dragon related. But what does my gut know?

  • They’ve learned about Wightserion and the Wall - while I think this could be very possible looking at Jon’s reaction (because he’d be angry at both himself and her, he’d feel guilty, question himself and his decisions etc) Dænerys’ behavior doesn’t seem fitting. Would she be this calm in this situation? Would she be understanding and soft? Or would she blame Jon? This is personal for her. And if he distances himself from her or they have a “you just had to have your bleeding truce” kind of fight, wouldn’t she be annoyed with him and feel like he’s disrespectful?

  • He’s learned about the Tarlys - Jon’s reaction fits. Not only will he have upset bannermen on his hands and be worried she’ll do something like that again, but he’s also not seen Sam in years and now they’re finally reunited and he brings with him the woman who murdered Sam’s father and brother. And it can definitely make Jon question his decisions. @thelawyerthatwaspromised wondered whether it’s Torrhen Stark’s statue he visits, and perhaps it is. Perhaps Jon’s questioning his “knee-bending” and what to do now. D*ny’s reaction fits this scenario too, because while I’m sure her first reaction would be to defend and justify herself, after Jon’s stormed off, she’d probably seek him out to smooth things over and make him see reason.

  • The dragons have eaten/burned people - I still think this fits rather well. If this takes place after they’ve inspected the feeding place (because those remains were there for a reason) and found skulls, his behavior fits. Like with the scenario above, he’d question what he’s done, whether bringing her north actually is worth it, and what they’re supposed to do now. He’d be angry at them both, feel incredibly guilty, and if it’s a child (or even children), that’s exactly the really horrifying scenario we’d need to understand just how dangerous dragons are. The dragons eating livestock isn’t enough.

And so on. I’m sure there are lots more possibilities.

And re: if we’re getting two crypts scenes.

Let’s say Jon doesn’t know yet. Once he does learn the truth, perhaps his first instinct isn’t to visit the crypts at all. If he’s upset enough, he might even avoid them and turn to the godswood to brood instead. And once he’s starting to get to terms with it, there simply might not be time for it because the shit hits the fan.

Perhaps we won’t get a post-parentage crypt scene until the final episode when all the wars are over and they can finally relax and start thinking about rebuilding. Or perhaps we’ll get several crypt scenes, who’ll all feel different because Jon’s mood will change and so will the characters with whom he shares the scene.

tl;dr: I really don’t think this scene is about the parentage reveal. It’s just what D&D want us to think. They absolutely use our bias to their advantage.

Thanks for the asks!

Perhaps Jon’s questioning his “knee-bending” and what to do now. D*ny’s reaction fits this scenario too, because while I’m sure her first reaction would be to defend and justify herself, after Jon’s stormed off, she’d probably seek him out to smooth things over and make him see reason.

  • The dragons have eaten/burned people - I still think this fits rather well. If this takes place after they’ve inspected the feeding place (because those remains were there for a reason) and found skulls, his behavior fits. Like with the scenario above, he’d question what he’s done, whether bringing her north actually is worth it, and what they’re supposed to do now. He’d be angry at them both, feel incredibly guilty, and if it’s a child (or even children), that’s exactly the really horrifying scenario we’d need to understand just how dangerous dragons are. The dragons eating livestock isn’t enough.

And so on. I’m sure there are lots more possibilities.

And re: if we’re getting two crypts scenes.

Let’s say Jon doesn’t know yet. Once he does learn the truth, perhaps his first instinct isn’t to visit the crypts at all. If he’s upset enough, he might even avoid them and turn to the godswood to brood instead. And once he’s starting to get to terms with it, there simply might not be time for it because the shit hits the fan.

Perhaps we won’t get a post-parentage crypt scene until the final episode when all the wars are over and they can finally relax and start thinking about rebuilding. Or perhaps we’ll get several crypt scenes, who’ll all feel different because Jon’s mood will change and so will the characters with whom he shares the scene.

tl;dr: I really don’t think this scene is about the parentage reveal. It’s just what D&D want us to think. They absolutely use our bias to their advantage.

Thanks for the asks!
trail.content:
Hi, anons!

Both the crypts scene and Jon and D*ny approaching the dragons make the audience assume two things based on popular theories and headcanons: 

  • After the reveal, Jon will seek out the crypts and D*ny will comfort him
  • At some point, D*ny will re-introduce him to the dragons and he’ll learn how to fly

So if things really are as obvious as they seem, it would ruin the suspense and tension of two very important scenes. D&D wouldn’t want to spoil that; therefore, I’m positive they put them in the trailer because our preconceived notions prevent us from figuring out what what’s really going on.

Exactly what’s going on, though…

That’s not normal brooding Jon. Copy his expression. How does it feel? The way he holds his mouth, the tension in his chin… Honestly, it’s not easy reading facial expressions when it’s this dark and the quality is so bad (and he’s out of focus too) so I’m probably a bit off. But I feel like he’s incredibly upset and holding back his anger and frustration and resentment. I think that’s the feeling I’m looking for. Not purely. He’s sad too and almost a bit despondent, but there’s resentment there, something he can’t let her see, and so he can’t even let his lip twitch the way it does when he’s trying to control his anger.

And considering how not welcoming he is to her, how he doesn’t reach out, doesn’t start turning his face toward her until she’s really close, and his expression doesn’t change… His reason for being upset has to do with her in some capacity–and she knows it. This isn’t a normal thing for her to do, to reach out like this, so softly and tentatively.

So what can it be?

  • The Dothraki have raided a settlement - I find this less likely, tbh. My gut says it’s dragon related. But what does my gut know?

  • They’ve learned about Wightserion and the Wall - while I think this could be very possible looking at Jon’s reaction (because he’d be angry at both himself and her, he’d feel guilty, question himself and his decisions etc) Dænerys’ behavior doesn’t seem fitting. Would she be this calm in this situation? Would she be understanding and soft? Or would she blame Jon? This is personal for her. And if he distances himself from her or they have a “you just had to have your bleeding truce” kind of fight, wouldn’t she be annoyed with him and feel like he’s disrespectful?

  • He’s learned about the Tarlys - Jon’s reaction fits. title: About Jon Riding Rhaegal
body:
So with new Game of Thrones content comes new debates. The new S8 trailer released this week hinted at Jon Snow possibly riding Rhaegal at some point this upcoming season. Personally, I think the last two Targaryens riding dragons side by side is pretty awesome but others think differently. Everyone is welcome to their opinion but I’m seeing some arguments pop up that’s against Jon riding a dragon that don’t quite hold up. First up,

“Dragon bonding is a life long process. That’s why Targaryens put dragon eggs in their baby’s crib. There isn’t enough time for Jon to bond with Rhaegal”

Meh. Not quite. Here is what GRRM has to say about dragon riding:

“As to when and how various Targaryens have become dragonriders…well, it varies. And I think that is realistic, based on what I have seen and learned from my real world friends who rides horses. Some begin to ride when they are very young, some as teenagers, some not until adulthood. There are even cases of riders who don’t get on a horse till retirement. Horses vary, people vary, and so do dragons and their riders. “

 Not A Blog: Fire & Blood: On the Way (April 25, 2018), Comment (May 2, 2018)

Maegor the Cruel by choice didn’t ride a dragon until he was 25.

“Though a dozen hatchlings had been born admist the fires of Dragonstone in the later years of Aegon’s reign, and were offered to the prince, he refused them all.”

“Lady Alyssa teased him about it one day in court, wondering aloud whether ‘my good-brother is afraid of dragons’. Prince Maegor darkened in rage at the jape, then replied coolly that there was only one dragon worthy of him”

Fire and Blood, The Sons of the Dragon

He wanted his father’s dragon Balerion and quickly bonded and rode Balerion after his father’s death.

“…until Prince Maegor appeared in the sky above, astride Balerion. The Conqueror’s younger son had claimed a dragon at last: none other than the Black Dread, the greatest of them all”

Fire and Blood, The Sons of the Dragon

Another example of adult dragonriders is the “Sowing of the Seeds” during the Dance of the Dragons. In 129 AC, the brutality of the war left the Blacks with too many dragons and not enough dragonriders. Prince Jacaerys put out a call to Targaryen bastards (“Dragonseeds”) and any other brave souls willing to mount a dragon:

“It was to them that Prince Jacaerys turned, at the urging of his fool, vowing that any man who could master a dragon would be granted lands and riches and dubbed a knight. His sons would be ennobled, his daughters wed to lords, and he himself would have the honor of fighting beside the Prince of Dragonstone against the pretender Aegon II Targaryen and his treasonous supporters”

Fire and Blood, The Dying of the Dragons-The Red Dragon and the Gold

Sixteen men failed and were killed by dragons.Three times that number were maimed and burned. But four prevailed, Hugh the Hammer, Ulf the Sot, Addam Velaryon, and Nettles. We are told this about how Nettles was able to master Sheepsteeler:

“In the end, the brown dragon was brought to heel by the cunning and persistence of a “small brown girl” of six-and-ten, who delivered freshly slaughtered sheep every morning, until Sheepstealer learned to accept and expect her”

Fire and Blood, The Dying of the Dragons-The Red Dragon and the Gold

We don’t have details on what the other three new dragonriders did to bond with their dragons. But the fact they were able to bond and ride their dragons in the middle of a war means the process must not have been that complicated. If Dany is a willing teacher (which it seems she is) then its possible for Jon to ride  Rhaegal before the Battle of Winterfell.

And the dragon egg in the cradle tradition? It isn’t some ancient Valyrian ritual brought over from the Freehold. Rhaena Targaryen started it in 36 AC:

“It was Princess Rhaena, legend says, who put a dragons’ egg in Princess Alysanne’s cradle, just as she had for Prince Jaehaerys two years earlier.”

Fire and Blood, The Sons of the Dragon

This seems to be more a family tradition then something that is actually necessary to bond with a dragon. The Targaryens mounted dragons for hundreds of years on Dragonstone before the egg in the cradle became a thing.

So judging by the lore evidence, yes, it is possible for Jon to quickly bond and ride Rhaegal during S8. Then again, the trailer can be a massive misdirect and Jon has no plans to mount a dragon. We will find out in six weeks!

summary: i've notices jon's battle shot is blue compared to the orange/red of the other wf battle shots. do you think he isn't there at...
question: i've notices jon's battle shot is blue compared to the orange/red of the other wf battle shots. do you think he isn't there at the time, arrives post battle to see the destruction or is his shot from the 2nd battle? there's no one else in jon's battle shot, there's something slightly off about it. do you any thought? thanks
answer:
There are plenty of shots without the fire. Davos on the battlements; ser Jorah and the Dothraki; Grey Worm, Missandei, and the Unsullied; Brienne, Podrick, and the KotV etc. They all seem to be taking place before the battle, though, as they prepare themselves to fight. And the orange shots seem to be on the battlements while the battle is raging on. The Jon shot, however, is probably outside the walls of Winterfell, so I don’t find it odd.

The first thing that popped into my head when I saw this snippet was a scene in s2 of Buffy the Vampire Slayer. She’s lured away by an enemy and realizes a little too late that it’s only a distraction to get her out of the way so they could get to her friends. And so she just legs it to get back to them–and of course arrives too late. Her friends have already been attacked and one of them died. It’s one of those scenes that sticks with you. All these years later, even though I don’t really remember much of the actual episode anymore, I still remember how engrossed I was and that growing sense of dread and panic as you watch her running even though it’s pointless. So, yeah, that’s where my mind went. 

It’s quite possible that they’re fighting the army of the dead on the fields outside, only for Jon to realize Winterfell itself is under attack (either by more dead or the GC) and he rushes there instantly. Or he sees someone he loves fighting against impossible odds. Or he’s caught sight of Wightserion and is rushing toward a scorpion. Or, as I know others have speculated, Sansa’s been taken and he rushes after them until she’s out of sight and he realizes he can’t do shit about it.

I don’t know. It does look as if he has his sword drawn, though, and his gaze if very focused. So he definitely has a goal in mind.

That’s all I’ve got.

Thanks for the ask!
